title: Lightning Creek Fire
field_incident_overview: The Lightning Creek Fire was ignited by lightning on 7/30/2025. It is burning up the Lightning Creek Drainage in the 2018 Cougar Fire scar.

title: Island Creek
field_incident_overview: The Island Creek fire was detected the evening of July 31, 2025. The fire is burning in steep terrain on the Moose Creek Ranger District near Sob Point, approximately 14 air miles north of Elk City, ID. It is approximately 11 air miles southeast of Lowell, ID.

title: Leroux Fire
field_incident_overview:
At approximately 2:30 PM on Sunday, August 3rd, a smoke report was called in to Delta Dispatch in the area of Oak Mesa outside of Hotchkiss, Colorado. What had been originally reported as a single tree fire was discovered to be over an acre in size by the local fire agency, located in steep, remote terrain with dangerous conditions for engagement. It was determined to be on BLM land and command was handed over to the agency when they arrived on scene. 

Fire behavior was extreme through the morning of August 4th and evacuations were ordered by Delta County Sheriff's Office at approximately 2:30 AM in the area along 3100 Road north of the Redlands Mesa Road intersection. 

The fire was very active during the day on Monday, fueled by Red Flag conditions. Thanks to the hard work of firefighters and heavy equipment operators on the ground coupled with multiple aerial resources applying water and retardant for most of the day on Monday, August 4th, growth of the fire was slowed and the fire behavior was reduced to a level at which firefighters were able to engage it directly by the end of shift. Team Colorado, a State Type 3 IMT, took command of the fire on Tuesday, August 5 at 6 AM. 

Command of the Leroux Fire was transferred back to the BLM Southwest District Fire Management Unit at 6:30 AM on Saturday, August 9. It was declared contained on August 12 and suppression repair efforts were completed on August 17th.

title: Rosa Fire
field_incident_overview:
Rosa Fire Last Update          Final Rosa Fire Map         

The fire remains within the existing perimeter, no growth is expected. Fire Suppression repair has been completed.  

Management of the fire has been turned back to the local units (Riverside County Fire, and the San Bernardino National Forest.

title: 2025 BDF Gold Fire
field_incident_description: Wildfire
field_incident_overview:
INITIAL SITUATION: San Bernardino National Forest firefighters responded to reports of a wildfire one mile NE of Holcomb Valley Campground in Big Bear, in the morning of Monday, August 4th, 2025. Holcomb Valley Campground was evacuated and remains closed.  Local Forest road closures are now in effect. 

 

CURRENT SITUATION: 

The ending size of the Gold Fire is 1036 acres due to more accurate mapping of the fire perimeter. Today the San Bernardino National Forest Type 3 Team is taking over the fire.  Mop-up, suppression repair, mitigating hazard trees and putting out the few places with a little smoke in the interior of the fire area are the main tasks in cleaning up this fire.  An excavator will also be working to move rocks back in place along the John Bull Trail that were moved for firefighter entry.  It will also be used to deck the logs of cut hazard trees.

Note that this is the final current situation update unless significant activity occurs.


FOREST VISITORS: A Temporary Forest Closure Order 05-12-52-25-03 has been implemented. Holcomb Valley Campground, John Bull Trail, and Holcomb Valley, are being impacted by the Gold Fire. Snags (dead standing trees), and widow-makers (broken limbs suspended in tree branches) ash pits (large holes filled with hot ash and embers from incinerated trees and shrubs), equipment and fire personnel are some of the many safety risks to the public. For your safety and the safety of our firefighters please honor the Forest Order and stay clear of the closed area.

This order is a temporary order and will remain in place until September 7, 2025. The San Bernardino National Forest has 900 miles of Off Road trails for your enjoyment during the closure.

The full closure order and map can be viewed here: https://www.fs.usda.gov/r05/sanbernardino/alerts/gold-fire-area-closure

 

AREA CLOSURES: The following recreation sites and Forest Service roads are temporarily closed for fire personnel and public safety.

title: Elk RBX Fire
field_incident_overview:
The Elk fire was discovered on Saturday, August 2nd as a lightning strike on private land in the Oak Ridge area. Drought with severe and extreme weather conditions along with two days of red flag warning caused heightened fire activity. Residences were evacuated from the area. As weather conditions changed and remained favorable for the Elk Fire, crews were able to gain substantial line around the Elk Fire. 

The Elk Fire is currently reported as being 100% contained; local resources are managing the incident and are being logistically supported by the Lee Fire.

title: Stoner Mesa Fire
field_incident_overview:
The Stoner Mesa Fire is burning along Stoner Creek and on Taylor Mesa in mixed conifer with substantial dead standing and down trees. Fire behavior has been extreme due to the prolonged lack of moisture, low humidity levels, and strong, shifting winds. During afternoon/early evening burn periods there has been group tree torching and spotting ahead of the main fire. Access to much of the fire area has been limited, due to mountain topography, heavy fuel loading and fire intensity.

Firefighters are implementing actions intended to keep the fire out of communities and private property along the Highway 145 corridor and the County Road 38 corridor. Structure Protection groups are working in both corridors, assessing structures, limbing trees and trimming grasses and installing sprinkler systems to proactively protect structures potentially impacted by the fire.

Closures: A Fire Area Closure Order is in effect for the Stoner Mesa Fire Area, Road and Trail Closure #Order No.: 02-13-05-25-14; This Order shall be in effect from August 6, 2025, at 12:00 a.m. through December 31, 2025, at 12:00 a.m., unless rescinded.

Evacuations: Dolores County has issued a "SET" status notification for County Road 38, from the Dolores County Line to the West Dolores Campground, and a "READY" status notification for the town of Rico. Learn more: https://www.facebook.com/DoloresCountyEmergency 

An interactive evacuation web map is available at https://tinyurl.com/StonerMesaEvacMap

Any Dolores County evacuations would be announced by Dolores County Emergency Alerts.

Sign up for Dolores County Emergency Alerts at https://member.everbridge.net/index/311578402488579

Sign up for Montezuma County Emergency Alerts at https://member.everbridge.net/337829242601830

 

Important links regarding fire information, evacuations, smoke outlooks, etc. https://linktr.ee/StonerMesaFirePIO

title: Lee Fire
field_incident_overview:
The Lee and Grease fires were discovered on August 2nd as lightning strikes on Bureau of Land Management managed land in the Piceance Creek area. The Lee and Grease fires quickly met to be known exclusively as the Lee fire. Drought with severe and extreme weather conditions along with multiple days of red flag warnings and heightened fire activity, the Lee fire grew over 100,000 acres in eight days. Firefighters have been working to find areas of opportunity in the southern area of the fire to reduce spread.

title: Bronco Fire
field_incident_description: The Bronco Fire is a full suppression wildfire.
field_incident_overview: The Bronco Fire is footprint is on the San Carlos Apache Agency, located 30 miles northeast of San Carlos, Arizona. The lightning-caused fire was reported on on August 3, 2025 burning in timber, chaparral, and brush.

title: Gill Gulch Fire
field_incident_overview:
The Gill Gulch Fire was reported August 4th and is located approximately seven miles south of Lincoln, MT. The fire is in patrol status and firefighters continue to monitor the fire daily for heat and work on mop-up operations.

There are no closures in place.

title: Bear Creek II
field_incident_overview: The Bear Creek II fire is a lightning-caused fire located on the Confederated Tribes of the Colville Reservation. Command of the fires will be transferred back to Mt. Tolman Fire Center on Thursday morning, August 14, 2025.

title: Beulah Fire
field_incident_overview:
The Beulah Fire is 52% complete. Completion speaks to the amount (percent) of objectives completed and more accurately captures and reports the specific amount of work accomplished on the ground to manage fire spread and reduce the negative impacts to communities, infrastructure, and other identified values. 

The Beulah Fire was reported on August 7 and is burning on the north slope of the Uinta Mountains within the High Uintas Wilderness on the Evanston-Mountain View Ranger District. The fire is approximately 7.5 miles southeast of the Bear River Ranger Station along Highway 150.

title: Vereda Blanca Wildfire Mt Taylor Ranger District
field_incident_description: Wildfire northeast Mt Taylor Ranger District near Black Mesa and northeast of Grants, NM.
field_incident_overview:
A fire start was reported on the Mt. Taylor Ranger District on August 8th, 2025 at 0731. Smoke may be visible west of the surrounding areas of Albuquerque, Santa Fe, Cuba and Jemez. Multiple firefighting resources on scene with additional response of engines and aerial resources. No road closures or evacuations are in effect.

Thanks to a significant decrease in fire activity and increased containment efforts, Southwest Incident Management Team 3 has transferred command of the Vereda Blanca Fire to a Type 3 Management Team led by Incident Commander Robert Morales. The next update will be when significant changes occur.
field_title_and_unit: NMCIF Vereda Blanca Wildfire Mt Taylor Ranger District

title: Indian Creek
field_incident_description: The Indian Fire is a full suppression wildfire.
field_incident_overview: The Indian Creek Fire started August 5, 2025, on the Fort Apache Indian Reservation. It was burning in grass, brush, Juniper and Ponderosa Pine in steep and rugged terrain that was challenging for firefighters to access.

title: White Sage Fire Burned Area Emergency Response BAER
field_incident_overview:
The White Sage Fire was started by lightning on July 9, 2025, near the community of White Sage approximately 15 miles southeast of Fredonia, Arizona, on the Bureau of Land Management’s Arizona Strip District. The wind-driven fire quickly grew onto the North Kaibab Ranger District despite the efforts of wildland firefighters who were able to respond a short time after the fire was first detected.

Driven by hot, dry, windy weather, the fire quickly grew and crossed onto the North Kaibab Ranger District by July 10. Command of the fire transferred command to the Color Country Team 2 Incident Management Team July 10 and was transferred on July 13 to Great Basin Complex Incident Management Team 6. 

A Burned Area Emergency Response (BAER) Team was ordered to assess the effects of the White Sage Fire to critical Forest Service values within the fire perimeter. The Team, led by BAER Team Leader Paul Brown, began assessing the Fire on August 1 and completed their findings and recommendations briefing to the Forest leadership on August 11.
field_title_and_unit: AZKNF White Sage Fire Burned Area Emergency Response BAER

title: Mountain Fire
field_incident_description: The Mountain incident is located near the area of the Mammoth fire which burned in July.  U.S. Forest Service-Modoc National Forest  Fire resources, including engines, crews, and fire suppression aircraft, are responding to a new fire incident visible from HWY 139 near Casuse Mountain with more resources on order. The Mountain Fire is approximately 250 acres burning in grass and brush with a moderate rate of spread.
field_incident_overview:
🔥8/12 Mountain Fire update 3:30 PM  🔥

The Mountain Fire is currently 30% contained at 980 acres, with no significant growth reported. The aerial support during this incident has been crucial, aiding in the fire line construction for the firefighters working on the ground. 

Today, crews are continuing mop-up operations, focusing on full suppression and containment of the fire. 

**Fire Weather:** Isolated critical conditions are expected today and Wednesday due to gusty winds and low relative humidity (RH). Dry conditions are expected to persist throughout the week, with temperatures gradually returning to near seasonal norms. A dry front is predicted to move through the region today and continue into Wednesday, which may bring increased wind speeds. These winds, coupled with low daytime RH, could create isolated areas of critical fire weather conditions. 

The public is urged to stay clear of areas where firefighters are actively working and to help prevent new fires from starting.

title: Rock Fire
field_incident_overview:
The Rock Fire was detected at 12:37 a.m. on August 13, 2025. It was one of several lightning-caused fires that started between the evening of August 12 and the early morning hours of August 13 across the Boise and Payette National Forests. Located approximately 1.5 miles south of Tamarack Resort, some of the smaller fires in the area were extinguished, while others merged into what is now the Rock Fire.

The fire is burning in rugged, mountainous terrain, with steep slopes on the northwest and southeast flanks. The subalpine fir understory holds a heavy load of dead and downed fuels, contributing to challenging fire behavior and intensity. 

Evacuations

Valley County West Mountain Road evacuation zone, WM07, has been elevated to "Set". The two other evacuation zones, West Mountain Road Zones WM05 and WM06, remain in "Ready" status as set by the Valley County Sheriff on August 13. Residents and visitors are encouraged to stay alert to changing conditions and follow all local authority guidance. For the most up-to-date evacuation and closure information, please visit: Valley County Evacuation Map. 

Closures

The Boise National Forest and Payette National Forest implemented an area, road, and trail closure and can be found at https://www.fs.usda.gov/r04/boise/alerts/rock-fire-area-road-and-trail-closure and https://www.fs.usda.gov/r04/payette/alerts.

title: King Fire
field_incident_overview:
INITIAL SITUATION: A brush fire was reported at 1:00 am in the morning east of interstate 5 and north of Smokey Bear Rd. In the early hours of the fire, firefighters experienced dangerous rates of spread and the fire quickly grew to over 100 acres. The fire has continued to burn south towards Vista Del Lago. Two unoccupied RV's were destroyed at the Pyramid Lake RV park early on in the incident. The fire has attempted to cross Interstate 5 three times.

 

CURRENT CONDITION: The King fire is 100% contained. All road closures have been lifted.

 

KNOW WHERE YOU CAN FLY: Drones pose a serious risk to firefighting and can cause air operations to cease. When drones interfere with firefighting efforts, a wildfire has the potential to grow larger and cause more damage. A FAA Temporary Flight Restriction (TFR) is in effect and any private aircraft or drone that violates the TFR could face serious criminal charges. For more information on drones the public can visit the FAA’s website at www.KnowBeforeYouFly.org “If you fly, we can’t!”

title: Horn Fire
field_incident_description:
The Horn fire is located on private property and DNRC-managed land between Cliff Lake and Highway 87 in Madison County, near the Montana-Idaho border. Fuels in the area are primarily grass and brushy fuels.

Horn Creek Road, Cliff Lake Road, and Wade Lake Road are open as of 8/18. Wade Lake and Cliff Lake are also open to the public.

Ground resources currently on scene include engines, 1 excavator and 1 dozers.
field_incident_overview:
The Horn Fire was reported around 2:30 pm on Wednesday, August 13th. The cause of fire was lightning. 

As of Thursday 8/21, the Horn Fire is 2,800 acres and 95% contained. Moderate winds yesterday supported fire control efforts and the fire is now creeping and smoldering. 

Crews are working on mop up activities around the entire perimeter of the fire. Mop up activities include turning over and mixing smoldering materials and applying water to remaining hot spots. Mop up has been completed 1 chain (66 feet) along the entire perimeter of the fire. 

Resources will continue mop up operations with the objective of creating a cold, secure buffer of 3 chains (198 feet) in from the perimeter. Personnel will also work to suppress activity within the small interior heat patches. Once that is complete, the incident will continue to reduce in complexity and the incident commander will begin to release the resources currently assigned. Remaining resources will continue to patrol the fire to extinguish any remaining hot spots and ensure that the fire does not pose a threat to surrounding areas. 

The weather will remain hot and dry, with the chance for gusty and erratic winds in the fire area. Firefighters ask that everyone use caution when recreating this weekend to avoid causing additional fires. Secure chains when towing, and check MTFireInfo.org for fire restrictions. Beaverhead and Madison County are in Stage 1 restrictions, meaning campfires are not allowed unless in a developed campground with an established ring. Always fully extinguish your campfire until it is cold to the touch.

title: Summer Springs Fire
field_incident_overview: At approximately 1pm on 8/13/2025, the Summer Springs Fire was reported 13 miles Southeast of Custer, Montana.

title: Elkhorn Fire - Salmon-Challis National Forest
field_incident_description: Wildfire
field_incident_overview:
The Elkhorn Fire started on July 29th around 5 pm and was lightning caused. The fire is burning approximately 33 miles northwest of Stanley and is burning on a cliff face adjacent to the Middle Fork of the Salmon River and approximately seven river miles from Boundary Boat Launch.

Firefighters are using a confine (confine involves restricting the fire to a predetermined area, often using natural barriers or fuel breaks) and a point protection strategy (a wildfire response strategy which protects specific assets or highly valued resources from the wildfire without directly halting the continued spread of the wildfire). 

Fire managers are using infrared flights supplemented with reconnaissance flights as appropriate. This strategy limits exposure to firefighters and maximizes firefighting resources for other wildfires that may be discovered.

Smoke from the Elkhorn Fire is drifting into the Challis area and smoke from the fires to the east in central Idaho is drifting into the Salmon area this evening.
field_title_and_unit: IDSCF Elkhorn Fire SalmonChallis National Forest

title: Sunset Fire
field_incident_overview: The Sunset Fire was first reported at approximately 3:30 PM August 13, 2025, northeast of Athol, Idaho, and is burning along the western shore of Lake Pend Oreille. The fire is burning in steep, heavily forested terrain that is difficult for ground crews to access, requiring the use of helicopters and boats to support suppression efforts. Smoke is visible from surrounding communities and across the lake. Firefighters are working to protect nearby structures and natural resources while prioritizing public and firefighter safety.

title: Crescent Road
field_incident_overview: The Crescent Road fire is located primarily between Crescent Road and Devil’s Gap Road at the northeast corner of Lincoln County and western edge of Spokane County. It started at approximately 4 pm on August 13, 2025. A state mobilization request was authorized at 7 pm on August 13, 2025 with two strike teams arriving August 14th. Northeast Washington Team 2 took over the fire at 10 am on August 14th allowing for additional resources to support suppression efforts.

title: Washington Fire
field_incident_overview:
The lightning caused Washington Fire was discovered on Wednesday, August 13, 2025. Firefighters are working to fully suppress the fire, with the top priority being the safety of both the public and firefighters.

As of Friday, August 15, 2025 at 0600, the Washington Fire is being managed by Southwest Complex Incident Management Team 1, led by Incident Commander, Carl Schwope.

title: Bivens Creek
field_incident_overview:
The Bivens Creek fire was reported on August 13, 2025, around 6:16. It is located approximately 15 miles north of Virginia City, MT. The fire is burning just to the southwest of Ramshorn Mountain. The fire area consists of thick subalpine fir timber, with a large "snag" or hazard tree component and a high concentration of dead and downed fuels. The cause of the fire was from a thunderstorm. 

Team members from Northern Rockies Incident Management Team 6,  a Complex Incident Management Team (CIMT), took command of the fire on August 17, 2025  at 7:00p.m. The team brings significantly more resources to support the Madison Ranger District’s goals and priorities when it comes to the full suppression of these fires.

Information about Air Quality can be found on the Fire and Smoke Map located on the AirNow website.  

A National Forest System Area Closure is in effect for the Bivens and Cloudrest Fires.  The purpose of this Order is for public health and safety due to the Cloudrest and Bivens Fires. As depicted on Attachment A, the area closed by this Order is as follows: Sections 15-36 (T3S R4W), Sections 15-22 and 28-33 (T3S R3W), Sections 1-4, 9-15, 22-27 and 34-36 (T4S R4W), Sections 1-36 (T4S R3W),and  Sections 1-12 (T5S R3W).

There is a Temporary Flight Restriction in place over the fire area. The TFR is in place to provide a safe environment for firefighting aircraft operations. The TFR extends for seven nautical miles from the surface of the ground up to and including 15,000 feet. 

Using drones and flying private aircraft in the fire area can halt air operations and suppression efforts, jeopardizing the safety of all firefighting resources.

field_incident_overview: The Red Canyon fire was reported on Wednesday, August 14th east of Thermopolis, WY in Hot Springs County.  The fire is burning on a combination of BLM, state, and private lands.  Full-suppression efforts are underway.

title: Windy Rock Fire
field_incident_overview:
EVACUATION ORDER

Evacuation orders are now in place for all residents in the OS Properties/Garnet Mountain Property Association-reformation area - South of Helmville, MT. Law Enforcement along with Fire Service personnel are assisting and will be making contact door to door. Please leave immediately!

___________________________________________________________________________

This fire is jointly managed between the Bureau of Land Management and the Montana Department of Natural Resources & Conservation (DNRC). The Montana DNRC County Assist Team, led by David Hamilton, assumed command of the Windy Rock Fire at 8 am on August 16. This fire is being managed under a full suppression strategy.

A new start, the Devil Mountain Fire, caused by a lightning strike holdover from the weekend, started in the Wilderness Study Area to the northwest of Windy Rock Fire. This fire grew to 372 acres in a matter of hours, making a run toward the northwest corner of the Windy Rock Fire.

Firefighter and public safety remain the top priority while implementing a safe, aggressive full suppression strategy for both the Windy Rock and Devil Mountain fires using both direct and indirect tactics and minimizing impacts to private land when possible.

title: Dragon Bravo Fire - DOI Burned Area Emergency Response - BAER
field_incident_overview:
On August 21, a Department of the Interior Burned Area Emergency Response (BAER) Team arrived at the Dragon Bravo Fire to identify potential risks to human life and safety, as well and critical natural and cultural resources in Grand Canyon National Park and on BLM-Arizona Strip District lands.

The BAER program is designed to address emergency stabilization issues related to wildland fire and prescribes emergency treatments to minimize threats to life and property resulting from the effects of fire. The program also addresses fire-damaged lands that are unlikely to recover naturally and to repair or replace minor facilities damaged by fire that are not critical to life and safety. This may include restoring native plant communities, treating noxious weed infestations, stabilizing trails, and replacing interpretive signs that were impacted by the fire.  

Team members are from the Bureau of Land Management, US Fish and Wildlife Service, Bureau of Indian Affairs, National Park Service, and US Forest Service. The BAER team will produce a BAER Plan specific to the Dragon Bravo Fire which will identify measures to reduce hazards and reduce further resource damage.

For more information on fire suppression efforts on the Dragon Bravo Fire, please visit the Dragon Bravo Fire Inciweb page.
field_title_and_unit: AZGCP Dragon Bravo Fire DOI Burned Area Emergency Response BAER

title: Sleeper Ranch Fire
field_incident_overview:
The Sleeper Ranch fire experienced extreme fire behavior and rapid growth during the Initial Attack. Aircraft continue to work the fire today as additional ground resources work their way to the fire.  

A Type 3 Incident Management Team has been ordered and is enroute.

title: Cottonwood Peak
field_incident_overview:
The Cottonwood Peak Fire is burning in brush and grass 3 miles North or Tuscarora, NV. 

CURRENT SITUATION:

Firefighters continue to utilize all tools and resources available to build containment around the Cottonwood Peak Fire. On Friday, the structure protection group reinforced a multi-faceted protection strategy in and around Tuscarora.  Friday night operations will maintain a heavy presence in the area. High terrain driven winds pushed the fire to the west and southwest Friday with structure protection shifting quickly to aggressively work on protection of ranches in those areas both on the ground and through the air. Friday night operations will continue a strong push to protect priority values at risk in this area.
 

BE AWARE:

  • The Bureau of Land Management has temporarily closed Wilson Reservoir Campground.
  • The Humboldt-Toiyabe National Forest has temporarily closed the Wild Horse Crossing and Jack Creek campgrounds.
  • The Nevada Department of Transportation has closed Highway 226 between the intersection with Highway 225 to Maggie Summit Road.

title: Mire
field_incident_overview: The Mire Fire is a lightning caused fire burning near Mire Creek on the Nez Perce-Clearwater National Forests' Lochsa-Powell Ranger District.

title: McAllister Fire
field_incident_description:
The McAllister Fire is located on private, state, and BLM land 3 miles south or Norris, and 3 miles north of Ennis Lake, on either side of HWY 287. The fire is burning mainly grass and scattered patches of trees.
There is an evacuation warning for residents in the area between Bradley Creek, Shining Mountains West, and US Highway 287.
Ground resources currently on scene are 3 hand crews, multiple engines, and heavy equipment.
field_incident_overview:
The McAllister Fire was reported around 5:15pm, Saturday August 16th. The cause of the fire was lightning. 

As of Thursday morning, 8/21, the fire is estimated at 3,560 acres with 50% containment. There could be more smoke today as we are expecting changes in wind direction. There may be a chance for precipitation today. The fire is still creeping and smoldering, with little flare ups due to wind. 

Crews are working around the perimeter of the fire in creating 3-chain lengths around the entire perimeter (1-chain length is 66 feet) and combing the interior for heat patches.

Resources will continue operations with the objective to creating a cold, secure buffer around the entire perimeter. Personnel will also work to suppress activity within the small interior heat patches. 

The evacuation warning has been lifted as of 8/20/25 for the areas between Bradley Creek, Shining Mountains West and US Highway 287 (between mile markers 61 and 64). There are no current road closures in place.

The weather today, 8/21, will remain hot and dry with gusty winds and afternoon showers. Firefighters ask that everyone use caution when traveling through Norris to get to Ennis on HWY 287 as equipment is staged at the top of Norris Hill.

title: Knowles Fire
field_incident_overview: The Knowles Fire was reported on August 17, 2025. It is located along the Flathead River near the Full Curl Wildlife Management Area. The fire is being managed under a full suppression strategy by the Montana Department of Natural Resources & Conservation (DNRC)

title: Burned Area Emergency Response BAER Dragon Bravo USFS
field_incident_description: US Forest Service Burned Area Emergency response on the Kaibab National Forest portion of the Dragon Bravo Fire
field_incident_overview:
The Dragon Bravo Fire started early in the afternoon on Friday July 4th, 2025, by lightning on the North Rim of the Grand Canyon in Grand Canyon National Park. Suppression resources responded immediately. Firefighters constructed containment lines taking advantage of favorable terrain where possible to stop the fire spread.

On Friday July 11th, 2025, the Dragon Bravo Fire was affected by strong and unfavorable northwest winds associated with a passing weather front. Consequently, the Dragon Bravo Fire exhibited extreme fire behavior and jumped multiple containment features. In the following days fire behavior continued to be very active, driven by hot temperatures, low relative humidities, and continued strong winds. Facilities in the North Rim developed area were impacted during this time and damage assessments are ongoing. The fire moved onto the North Kaibab Ranger District of the Kaibab National Forest on July 23.

On Monday July 14th, 2025, at 6:00 am Southwest Complex Incident Management Team 4 took command of the Dragon Bravo Fire. They managed the fire until 6:00 am on Monday July 28th, 2025, when Southwest Complex Incident Management Team 2 took command of the fire.

On Sunday August 10th, 2025, Great Basin Complex Incident Management Team 7 assumed command of the Dragon Bravo Fire and will continue to manage the fire under a full suppression strategy while also ensuring firefighter/first responder and public safety.

In the last few days, suppression resources have made significant progress constructing and reinforcing containment lines. More favorable weather conditions have resulted in lower fire intensity in many areas. Suppression repair in select areas of the fire is in progress and will increase in the coming days. 

On Monday August 18, The Forest Service Burned Area Emergency (BAER) Team arrived to identify and manage potential risks to resources on National Forest System lands and reduce these threats through appropriate emergency measures to protect human life and safety, property, and critical natural or cultural resources on the Kaibab National Forest portion of the Dragon Bravo Fire.
field_title_and_unit: AZKNF Burned Area Emergency Response BAER Dragon Bravo USFS

title: La Plata
field_incident_description: The fire is burning in rugged terrain with heavy dead and down timber. Access is difficult, as much of the fire is in a non-motorized wilderness area.
field_incident_overview: The La Plata Fire was reported on August 17, 2025, at 5:46 p.m. The wildfire is located on the Pike-San Isabel National Forest Cimarron and Camanche Grasslands on the south side of Twin Lakes Reservoir approximately 4 miles southwest of Twin Lakes, Colorado.

title: One Way Fire
field_incident_description: Discovered late Tuesday afternoon August 19, by the Bureau of Land Management (BLM) Arizona Strip District while checking a remote lookout camera, the fire is likely a hold over from recent lightning activity.
field_incident_overview:
News Release
BLM Arizona Strip District 

Media Contact: Rachel T. Carnahan, rcarnahan@blm.gov, 435-688-3303

August 22, 2025 

 

Wildfire Fact Sheet – One Way Fire 

Multiple fire resources dispatched to One Way Fire 

 

Start Date: Discovered late Tuesday afternoon August 19, by the Bureau of Land Management (BLM) Arizona Strip District while checking a remote lookout camera, the fire is likely a hold over from recent lightning activity. 

Location: Approximately 38 miles south of St. George, UT, within Arizona

 

Jurisdiction: Grand Canyon-Parashant National Monument, Arizona Strip District, Bureau of Land Management

 

Fire Size: 216 acres [Mapped August 19]

 

Containment: 95%

 

Cause: Lightning

 

Fuels: Grass, shrub, pinyon juniper

 

Structures: No structures threatened. Fire managers are requesting the public’s assistance by traveling cautiously in the area to allow fire resources to access the fire. 

 

Fire Crews/Resources: Firefighting resources from Color Country Interagency Fire including Bureau of Land Management, U.S. Forest Service and National Park Service are assisting on this fire: six engines, two water tenders, one Type 3 helicopter, and a three-person squad. 

 

 

Highlights: Crews will continue securing the perimeter and mop-up operations. For additional information, please contact the Arizona Strip Field Office at 435-688-3200 or check BLM Arizona Facebook or BLM Arizona Fire X/Twitter

 

-BLM-

 

The BLM manages roughly 245 million acres of public land located primarily in 12 western states, including Alaska, on behalf of the American people. The BLM also administers 700 million acres of sub-surface mineral estate throughout the nation. Our mission is to sustain the health, diversity, and productivity of America’s public lands for the use and enjoyment of present and future generations.

title: Derby Fire
field_incident_overview:
The Derby Fire was ignited by lightning on an extremely steep cliff face in a remote area near the Flat Tops Wilderness on Saturday evening. Initial attack efforts by smokejumpers on Sunday were hindered by rollout of burning material, repeatedly igniting the slope below the main fire. 

Protection of life and property are key objectives for managing this fire.

Northern Rockies Complex Incident Management Team 3 assumed command of the fire on the morning of Wednesday, August 20.

title: Sandbar 2 Fire
field_incident_description: Lightning/Natural
field_incident_overview: In the early afternoon on August 19, fire personnel responded to a smoke report just north of Flesher Pass. Fire personnel responded immediately utilizing both helicopters and airtankers to assist hand crews putting in direct line. Dry fuels, low humidity, and warm weather led to rapid fire growth on the Sandbar 2 fire. The fire continues to grow and remains active in steep, difficult-to-access terrain where there are high levels of dry, dead trees. Today, fire personnel continue to use a full suppression strategy and will be able to go direct assisted by very large airtankers and helicopter water drops. The fire is visible from Montana State Highway 279 and is less than one mile from private structures and land. Please be mindful of increased fire personnel on Flesher Pass Road #279 and slow down to protect our firefighters’ safety. Please avoid stopping on the road or pullouts as this affects firefighter safety and operations. On Friday August 22, at 0700 hrs., command of the fire was transferred to Northwest Complex Incident Management Team 8, with Ed Hyatt serving as Incident Commander.

title: West Fork Fire
field_incident_description: Wildfire
field_incident_overview:
The West Fork Fire Started on 8/19/2025, located 23 miles northwest of West Yellowstone, Montana, in the South Madison's just North of the Beaver Creek FS cabin, Hebgen Ranger District, Custer Gallatin National Forest.

The fire does not currently pose a threat to Big Sky. Please stay away from aviation working at Hebgen Lake. Aviation aircraft may be dipping out of Hebgen Lake. DO NOT operate drones in the fire area or the Hebgen Lake area, this will cause all firefighting aircraft to be grounded immediately. There is a temporary Flight Restriction in place in the fire area.

No evacuations ordered at this point in time.

title: Corral Creek Fire
field_incident_overview:
The Corral Creek fire is a wildfire that is approximately 6.5 miles south-southeast of Huson, Montana. The fire, which is burning in timber, was reported on August 20, 2025. As of August 22, 2025, the fire had grown to 221 acres and was 0% contained.

Firefighting efforts have included the use of helicopters to dump water, and Large Air Tankers dropped retardant to slow the spread. The Lolo National Forest is the lead protecting agency for the incident.

The cause of the fire is a lightning holdover.

title: Twin
field_incident_overview: The fire is currently burning on both sides of Forest Trail 101 – Indian Henry Ridge, Forest Service Road 5371.

title: Dollar Lake Fire
field_incident_overview:
The Dollar Lake Fire is burning in the Green River Lakes area of the Bridger-Teton National Forest's Pinedale Ranger District. The fire was reported at 2:16 p.m. on Thursday, August 21.

Dollar Lake is located along a 25-mile dirt and gravel road that follows the Green River through the national forest. The road is a popular camping and recreation site. In a matter of hours on Aug. 21, the wind-driven fire grew from 20 acres to 600 acres in size. The fast-moving fire prompted the Sublette County Sheriff's office to immediately issue a road closure and evacuation of the area.

The cause of the fire has not been determined.

The fire danger rating for the area remains at very high, and fire restrictions are in effect on the Bridger-Teton National Forest. Learn more by clicking this link to the Stage 1 Fire Restrictions, placed on August 12, 2025 (order #04-03-25-304)

title: Willow Creek
field_incident_overview:
The Willow Creek Fie was reported on Friday, August 22 on the Greys River District of the Bridger-Teton National Forest, burning in timber southwest of the town of Smoot. 

Initial resources included an engine and helitack working to suppress the fire. Air attack was on scene utilizing three helicopters and two air tankers. This is a full suppression fire.

The fire danger rating for the area remains at very high, and fire restrictions are in effect on the Bridger-Teton National Forest. Learn more by clicking this link to the Stage 1 Fire Restrictions, placed on August 12, 2025 (order #04-03-25-304)
